data.title: Set PivotX & PivotY of Image from Texture
Fix 'Sprite.clipRect = null'
data.body:
Hey Daniel -
The updated clipRect code breaks when you clear the clipRect with Sprite.clipRect = null - this is just a patch to fix that.

data.title: Textfield not rendering correctly when StageQuality.LOW
Flickering Starling Instance -- Running Multiple Starling Instances
data.body:
I have two Starling instances running in two separate Native Windows. In Starling instance ("A") I have a single image loaded, and in Starling instance ("B") I have a row-layout tiled list consisting of 30+ images. Everything looks fine until I start scrolling (via touch) through the tiled List in "B", Starling "A" starts rapidly flickering and the loaded image disappears and turns black. After manually resizing the Native Window of Starling "A", the flickering stops and seems to resolve itself for the current session. If I load another image into Starling "A" while it's flickering, it throws the following error:
Error: Error #3684: Texture creation failed. Internal error. at flash.display3D::Context3D/createTexture()
At first I thought this was related to issue #278, but it no longer appears so. Thoughts?

data.title: Error #3605: Sampler 0 binds an invalid texture -- Multiple Starling Instances
data.body:
I have two starling instances running in different Stage3Ds, each in it's own native window. All seems to work fine until I load in an image and set the Texture: ``` javascript var texture:Texture = Texture.fromBitmap(Bitmap(this.loader.content)); ``` It throws the following error:
Error: Error #3605: Sampler 0 binds an invalid texture. at flash.display3D::Context3D/drawTriangles()
If I only run one starling instance at a time, it seems to work fine. Any ideas on what could be causing this? Thanks! B

data.title: Scissor rect support for DisplayObjectContainer
data.body:
Hey Daniel,

I've ported my similar pull request from Sparrow (https://github.com/PrimaryFeather/Sparrow-Framework/pull/1070) to Starling. Basically, this adds a scissorRect getter/setter to DisplayObjectContainer. It shouldn't add any CPU overhead for code that doesn't use it.

(This also fixes a bug in the existing Starling scissor-rect code: RenderSupport.finishQuadBatch() needs to be called when the scissor rect changes)

data.title: Git branching model
data.body:
Hello everyone!

I would like to open discussion about branching for Starling Framework.

Now there is only one branch called "master" and I think project of that size should support a normal branching model.

For example, there is a "holy bible" model for that described [here](http://nvie.com/posts/a-successful-git-branching-model/)
It's not necessary to support all features of Successful Git Branching Model, but having a develop and master branches will be a huge step forward to better framework development.

Also, having a master and develop branches will help to improve Maven support, because now there is almost no way to make a release builds, because every commit to master is not stable. 

Anyone else agree with me?:)

data.title: MovieClip
Incomplete Documentation for display.QuadBatch
data.body:
Through the helpful people of the Starling forums I was able to discover the rest of the information required to properly make use of the display.QuadBatch class.

Josh suggested that I create an issue about missing documentation here, since the information is indeed required for QuadBatch to function-

the information being:

You must call 'QuadBatch.reset()' THEN add whatever Quads or Images you may desire; assuming you're continuously iterating for these Quads or Images within, or through a loop/every frame.

Also would be wise to include this information in, or update the information of your Starling Optimzation tips article to include this.

data.title: fontSize on TextInput component not compensating for contentScaleFactor
TextField auto-sizing
data.body:
(Re-created to merge cleanly with the latest Starling HEAD)

This adds auto-sizing capabilities to TextField, and is intended to address the #169 open issue.

Adds the ability to have TextFields automatically adjust their bounds
to the bounds of their text contents.

This works differently from Flash's native TextFieldAutoSize feature,
which is notoriously hard to use, and confusingly conflates auto-
sizing and alignment. There are two types of auto-sizing: SINGLE_LINE
and MULTILINE, which behave as expected. Use
TextField.autoSizeMaxWidth and autoSizeMaxHeight to control how auto-
sized text will be laid out.

Auto-sizing is incompatible with Starling's existing
TextField.autoScale feature; enabling one will disable the other.

data.title: Separate touch processing from dispatching
data.body:
(Re-created to cleanly merge with the latest starling HEAD)

Hey Daniel, here's the pull request with my minor refactor of TouchProcessor. This essentially breaks TouchProcessor into two different classes: TouchProcessor, which creates Touch objects, and TouchDispatcher, which implements a new TouchHandler interface and does the TouchEvent creation and dispatching.

Starling's default behavior and API are unchanged. There's a new property on the Starling class, 'touchHandler', which allows user code to install its own TouchHandler object and perform custom Touch input processing.

I've tested this code against the Starling demos and unit tests.

data.title: AssetManager loading complete issue...
Logging Feature Request
data.body: In the AssetManager, and anywhere else that there is logging, making the log function a parameter or make it protected so it can be extended. I like to write logs to a log file for devices that I can't do remote debugging on.

data.title: Allow custom formatting for TextField
data.body:
As I discussed in #262, this adds a `formatText` method onto `TextField`. It's super simple. 

I wrote a little repository to show what this can do [here](https://github.com/johnfn/RedGreenText). The meat is [this](https://github.com/johnfn/RedGreenText/blob/master/RedGreenText.as) file, which overrides `TextField` to render the text in a cute way.

data.body:
Whenever I turn on BlurFilter.createDropShadow in my app, I will get the above error after some time. The amount of time will vary, but it will eventually always happen. I can't easily reproduce this, but I'm using BlurFilter.createDropShadow for adding a drop shadow to text fields. I've attached a picture of the stack-trace since github won't allow me to attach a text file(?).

Any idea what happens?

data.title: [Suggestion] Extendible Movieclips
[Suggestion] .clone()
data.body: It may be nice to have a .clone() property on DisplayObject, MovieClip, Sprite, Image etc. Not a biggie tho if its a lot of work / bloat.

data.title: Feature Request - Absolute showStats positioning
Customize wrong wmode message
data.body: I have seen reports that the wrong wmode message sometimes appears, even if you have renderMode set to direct in the AIR app XML. I think it was on specific devices only, so maybe the hardware didn't support Stage 3D or something. The reason doesn't particularly matter. However, it would be nice if we could customize this message so that if it happens out in the wild, users can see a more friendly message.

data.title: Feature request - support for many TextFormats in TextField
data.body:
One thing I like to do in text in games is highlight certain words. You know: "Go get the _EPIC ORB_" and the like. Unfortunately, there's no way to apply many `TextFormat` objects to `starling.text.TextField`. I dug through the code and it seems like there's no trivial way to do this, since the `flash.text.TextField` is a static field shared between all `starling.text.TextFields`. 

My idea was that starling.text.TextField could provide an optional `formatText(textField: flash.text.TextField, textFormat: flash.text.TextFormat)` method that could be overridden in a subclass. The method would be called right before the text was rendered to the BitmapData, in `createRenderedContents`, and it'd pass in the flash TextField object as well as the current TextFormat applied to the starling TextField object. The subclass could apply whichever `TextFormat`s it desires, and then when they were done Starling would take care of the rest.

How do you guys feel about this idea? I figured I'd float the idea before writing a PR to ensure I didn't miss anything (and maybe you guys have a better suggestion).

data.title: Make TextureAtlas Texture accessible
data.body: For debug purposes I would like to display the texture in a TextureAtlas to the screen but unfortunately its marked as private and thus not accessible even by extension. Please make it either protected or public.

data.title: FragmentFilter Textures Converted to Powers of Two Produce Unexpected Results
data.body:
This isn't a bug, but as mentioned in the title, this can produce some unexpected results in any shaders relying on UV coordinates.

It may take a bit of explanation so please bear with me.

In the calculateBounds method of FragmentFilter.as, the bounding rectangle surrounding the filtered display object is calculated. The width and height of that rectangle is then bumped up to the next power of two. The texture that is filtered (and sent to to FragmentFilter's activate() method) is set to those dimensions.

Now say, for an example, I have a game with a character that for some stupid reason is 129 pixels tall. That character is standing in a pool of water, so I write a fragment shader to use as a filter. I pass the value .5 to that shader as I only want to apply the effect to the lower half of the texture (don't want the hero to drown :) ). The problem is, since the texture is now bumped up to the next power of 2, it now has a height of 256 so my water level, rather than being at the (129 \* .5) pixel mark is now at the 128 (256 \* .5) pixel mark. Assuming the filter effect is visible at all, it only affects the bottom row of pixels of my filtered image - not the whole bottom half of the character as I would have hoped.

As a work around, if you know the dimensions of your filtered object you can send a ratio to the  shader - something like (.5 \* actualHeight) / texture.height for example. If you don't know the actual size of your filtered object though (say you have scaling in place where objects are scaled by a user controlled camera or whatever) you can be in real trouble.

One solution would be to not bump up the object's bounds to the next power of 2. Simply commenting out the 2 lines of code which does that solves all problems. However, if that mod was added for future proofing or performance optimization, well, removing it would not be good.

Another idea is perhaps to temporarily save the object's bounds prior to the POT operation and send it to the FragmentFilter's activate() method. That way when writing your own filters you would have access to both a Rectangle instance representing the display objects actual dimension (height of 129 pixels in my example) and the Texture instance (with a height of 256 in my example). Then for UV calculations you can do something like I did above.

Something look at and consider anyway.

Thank you,
-Devon

data.title: Scaffold_Mobile for browser
data.body:
I'm using the Scaffold_Mobile for my game, using the AssetManager and everything works just perfect.It saved me a lot of time and I'm very thankful for that.

But I reached a point where I'd love to share my work in progress with some of my friends and I think showing the game in the browser with flash player would be very useful. 

Unfortunately I think the AssetManager uses some AIR-only classes which aren't available in the browser flash player.

I would love AssetManager to work both in the browser and in AIR.
Is there anything that can be done?

data.title: Tween: function to get end value for a property
data.body:
Something like this:

```
var endValue:Number = tween.getEndValue("x")
```

Use case: I have a running tween. I may need to change it's end value, but only in certain situations. I'd like the ability to compare the current end value before I decide what to do.

data.title: Event.RENDER or something similar?
data.body:
Is there an event that is triggered right before starling is about to render? If not, I think there should be.

Edit: Better yet, something like Event.EXIT_FRAME? Would saving having to import the native flash Event class alongside Starling's.

Current solution, if anyone is interested, is simply to override the `render()` method and do what you need to do, then remember to call `super.render()` at the end.

data.title: Error #3675 - Texture format mismatch. Only in device (IOS iPad).
data.body:
Forum topic: http://forum.starling-framework.org/topic/assets-manager-error-3675-texture-format-mismatch

In ADL (AIR Simulator) works fine,
but in device I receive this error on change of screens in device.

PS: Using the last versions of Starling and Feathers

I think I found the error: 
[Embed(source="/../../assets/textures/texture.png")]
public static const texture:Class;

Using a texture with name of "texture".

data.title: RenderTexture not disposing underlying textures properly
data.body:
forum topic: http://forum.starling-framework.org/topic/bug-rendertexture-not-disposing-underling-textures-properly?replies=3#post-20933

If you create a persistent RenderTexture, draw to it an odd number of times, then dispose it, one of the created textures will not be disposed.

This happens because when you instantiate a RenderTexture, it creates mActiveTexture, calls the SubTexture super constructor passing mActiveTexture, and later (if persistent) it creates mBufferTexture. When you call render, mBufferTexture and mActiveTexture are swapped, but the superclass SubTexture's mParent isn't. What happens when you call dispose on the RenderTexture is that it will dispose mBufferTexture (if persistent), then call super.dispose(), which will dispose mParent (which is now the same as mBufferTexture, since the swap on render), and mActiveTexture is never disposed.

data.title: AssetManager bug: Alphanumerical sorting error
data.body:
Array.sort(Array.CASEINSENSITIVE) does not support alphanumerical sorting.

Texture names:
Player1_run_1
Player1_run_2
Player1_run_3
...
Player1_run_10

Sorted output result:
Player1_run_1
Player1_run_10
Player1_run_11
Player1_run_2
Player1_run_20
...

Expected result:
Player1_run_1
Player1_run_2
...
Player1_run_10
Player1_run_11

Possible solution:
pass sort a method argument that is used for comparison.

Best regards,
Fernando
